gloss: Loss can lead to unexpected fortune.
teaser: What if a loss turned out to be a blessing in disguise?
script: Welcome to Chengyu Bites — your quick summary on Chinese 成语. What if a loss turned out to be a blessing in disguise? [break 1s] The phrase is: 塞翁失马, sàiwēngshīmǎ. [break 1s] 塞 (sài) - to stop, to block [break 0.5s] 翁 (wēng) - old man [break 0.5s] 失 (shī) - to lose [break 0.5s] 马 (mǎ) - horse [break 0.5s] Full idiom again: 塞翁失马; literally, 'the old man at the pass loses a horse,' which figuratively means that loss can lead to unexpected fortune. [break 1s] Here’s the story behind it: [break 1.5s] There was once an old man living near a border who lost his horse. His neighbors lamented his loss, but he simply said, 'Maybe it's a good thing.' Later, the horse returned with another horse, and the neighbors congratulated him. But the old man replied, 'Maybe it's not a good thing.' Soon after, his son fell from the new horse and broke his leg. While everyone was concerned, he again said, 'Maybe it's a good thing.' Eventually, war broke out, and his son was spared due to his injury. [break 1.5s] Example 1: 失去工作可能是塞翁失马的机会。 Lost a job could be a 塞翁失马 opportunity. [break 1s] Example 2: 他考试失利，但也许这就是塞翁失马的开始。 He failed the exam, but maybe this is the start of 塞翁失马. [break 1s] Example 3: 塞翁失马的故事让我明白了人生的无常。 The story of 塞翁失马 taught me about the unpredictability of life. [break 1s] In summary, 塞翁失马 means loss can lead to unexpected fortune. Thanks for listening to Chengyu Bites! See you next time for another idiom. [break 1s]
